item.title: Brexit: Johnson 'very confident' MPs will back deal
item.description: The PM is facing an uphill battle to get his new Brexit deal through the House of Commons on Saturday.

item.title: Turkey to suspend Syria offensive, Mike Pence announces
item.description: US Vice-President Mike Pence says the pause in operations will allow Kurdish-led forces to withdraw.

item.title: National Doral Miami: Trump Florida golf course to host G7 summit
item.description: The Doral Miami resort will host the summit but the president will not profit, the White House says.

item.title: Paul Gascoigne cleared of sex assault on train passenger
item.description: The ex-footballer has been cleared of both assault and sexual assault after kissing a woman on a train.

item.title: Drayton Manor to be prosecuted over Evha Jannath's death
item.description: Evha Jannath, 11, died after falling from Drayton Manor's Splash Canyon water ride in 2017.

item.title: Extinction Rebellion protesters dragged from Tube train roof
item.description: Extinction Rebellion says it will "take stock" of the reaction to the action for future protests.

item.title: E-fit released to identify man who fell from plane
item.description: The body of a man, believed to be Kenyan, was found in a garden in Clapham in June.

item.title: Trump and Pelosi: The 'meltdown' photo showing Washington divides
item.description: A photo of Democrat Nancy Pelosi at an explosive White House meeting on Syria is causing a stir.

item.title: Bulgaria authorities fine and ban four fans over racist abuse of England players
item.description: Four of the fans arrested by Bulgarian police for subjecting England players to racist abuse are fined and banned.

item.title: Duke and Duchess: Royal plane aborts landing after Pakistan storms
item.description: An RAF aircraft carrying the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge twice tried to land in Islamabad.

item.title: Facebook chief rules out banning political adverts
item.description: Mark Zuckerberg says he does not think it is right for a company to censor politicians or the news.

item.title: Stowaway cat found in hand luggage at airport security
item.description: Candy the cat is found inside a suitcase when it was scanned at airport security.

item.title: Kevin McCloud property firms face liquidation
item.description: People lent thousands of pounds to a company which was founded by the Grand Designs presenter.

item.title: Google Pixel 4 Face Unlock works if eyes are shut
item.description: Google confirms its new security system may unlock a person's device even if their eyes are shut.

item.title: Brexit: What is in Boris Johnson's new deal with the EU?
item.description: A revised Brexit deal has been agreed by the UK and EU. What does it contain?

item.title: Brexit deal: What does it mean?
item.description: Boris Johnson has agreed a new Brexit deal with the EU - but what does it mean and will Parliament pass it?

item.title: Brexit deal: Where have the UK and EU compromised?
item.description: After tense negotiations, both sides made concessions to reach a new deal.

item.title: Brexit: What happens now?
item.description: The British government and the EU have agreed a new Brexit deal, but will it get through Parliament?

item.title: Brexit deal: Why does the DUP's opinion matter?
item.description: BBC News NI assesses the new Brexit deal, why the DUP won't vote for it and why that matters.

item.title: Legal bid at Court of Session to stop MPs passing 'illegal' Brexit deal
item.description: Anti-Brexit campaigner Jo Maugham has lodged a petition at Scotland's highest civil court.

item.title: Nicola Sturgeon says Johnson deal would mean 'much harder Brexit'
item.description: Scotland's first minister confirms her SNP MPs will vote against Boris Johnson's newly-agreed deal with the EU.

item.title: Why is Banksy vetting the customers of his online store?
item.description: Anyone hoping to buy official merchandise from his new online store has to answer a question.

item.title: Prince William and Kate bowl over royal fans on Pakistan tour
item.description: The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge take to the crease on the fourth day of their visit to the country.

item.title: Ballet star Precious Adams on balancing roles with being a role model
item.description: Rising star of English ballet Precious Adams on unwittingly opening up a debate around colourism.

item.title: How plastic bags were supposed to help save the planet
item.description: Family of inventor says they were designed to be reused to stop trees from being destroyed.

item.title: Vatican launches new 'eRosary' bracelet
item.description: The gadget aims to help young Catholics pray for world peace and contemplate the gospel.

item.title: Birdsong plays in 5,000 buildings to highlight bird loss
item.description: Venues include London Underground stations, sports stadiums, supermarkets and Lincoln Cathedral.

item.title: The Derbyshire village recreated out of fruit cake
item.description: A baker spent three months constructing the sweet model of Eyam village in Derbyshire.

item.title: Online fashion twice as ‘racy’ as High Street
item.description: Online fashion stores are more likely than traditional ones to use images seen as "racy", BBC research finds.

item.title: Pakistan royal visit: Kate's outfits draw Diana comparisons
item.description: Is the Duchess of Cambridge putting a modern twist on garments the Princess of Wales wore years ago?

item.title: BBC News Channel
item.description: Britain's most-watched news channel, delivering breaking news and analysis all day, every day.

item.title: Harry Dunn death: Is extraditing Anne Sacoolas a realistic prospect?
item.description: What are the legal options that might provide Harry Dunn's parents with the details of his death?

item.title: The real (and fake) sex lives of Bella Thorne
item.description: The actress Bella Thorne opens up about sexuality, pornography, depression and feminism.

item.title: Which crimes are least likely to be solved?
item.description: Many crimes in the UK remain unsolved and many are not even reported - details in 10 charts.

item.title: My Money: 'BOOM, suddenly £14.99 less rich!'
item.description: As part of a new BBC blog series, Olivia Davies shares what she's spent her money on this week.

item.title: Leonardo da Vinci feud: The 'earlier' Mona Lisa mystery
item.description: A London family is battling an international consortium over a potentially priceless painting.

item.title: Can a new apple take over the world?
item.description: Apple growers in Washington state reckon their new variety, the Cosmic Crisp, will be a global hit.

item.title: Yungblud: A mouthpiece for the underrated youth
item.description: "We are not bratty kids fighting for attention. We understand what we want," says the pop star.

item.title: How dad saved son from 'scalding cuppa' scars
item.description: Each year hundreds of young UK children end up in hospital with severe but avoidable coffee and tea scalds, like Archie.

item.title: Charles Jencks: The architect who made cancer care a work of art
item.description: Charles Jencks believed the design of the centres inspired by his wife, Maggie, should lift the spirits of patients.

item.title: How Yorkshire Ripper's terror 'changed the world for women'
item.description: A new play in Leeds shows the impact of the Yorkshire Ripper's reign of terror on ordinary women.

item.title: Leicester-Liverpool Boxing Day game moved to 20:00 GMT for Amazon
item.description: Liverpool's Premier League trip to Leicester City on Boxing Day is moved to an 20:00 GMT start so it can be televised as part of Amazon's new contract.

item.title: Slade gets call as England drop Ford for Australia game
item.description: Head coach Eddie Jones drops George Ford for England's World Cup quarter-final against Australia, with Owen Farrell at fly-half and Henry Slade in the centre.

item.title: Day dies four days after suffering head injuries in Conwell fight
item.description: American boxer Patrick Day has died at the age of 27, four days after sustaining a brain injury in a fight against Charles Conwell.

item.title: On this day 2009: Darren Bent scores 'beach ball' goal for Sunderland against Liverpool
item.description: BBC Sport looks back at the moment Darren Bent scores for Sunderland with a deflection from a beach ball in a 1-0 win over Liverpool at the Stadium of Light.

item.title: MOTDx: Reece & Craig train like the professionals at Crystal Palace
item.description: MOTDx's Reece Parkinson and Craig Mitch go training with Premier League club Crystal Palace to see if they have what it takes to make it as a top-flight professional player.

item.title: Non-league: Basford United’s Stefan Galinski header from his own half against FC United
item.description: Watch as defender Stefan Galinski scores with a header from his own half for Basford United, who beat FC United 2-1 in the Northern Premier League.

item.title: Atletico Madrid v Villarreal: La Liga submits request to hold fixture in Miami
item.description: La Liga asks the Spanish Football Federation for permission to hold December's match between Atletico Madrid and Villarreal in Miami.
